CECCO Seneschal of the Castle . FULVIA COLONNA Under the duke 's protection . HELENA Sister to Haemon . GIULIA Serving Fulvia . PAULA Serving Helena . LYGIA } PHAON } Revellers . ZOE } BASIL }

div.head: ACT ONE

stage.stage: Scene .— The Island Leucadia . A ruined temple of Apollo near the town of Pharo . Broken columns and stones are strewn , or stand desolately about . It is night — the moon rising . ANTONIO , who has been waiting impatiently , seats himself on a stone . By a road near the ruins FULVIA enters , cloaked .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: Ah , you ? My father 's unforgetting Fulvia ?

sp.speaker: FULVIA
sp.p: At least not Helena , whoe'er she be .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: And did I call you so ?

lg.l: : Unless it is
These stones have tongue and passion .
: Then the night
Recalling dreams of dim antiquity 's
Heroic bloom worked on me .— But whence are
Your steps , so late , alone ?
: From the Cardinal ,
Who has but come .
: With doom
The moody bolt of Rome broods over us .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: My father will not bind his heresy ?

sp.speaker: FULVIA
sp.p: You with him walked to-day . What said he ? ANTONIO : I ? With him to-day ? Ah , true . What may be done ?

lg.l: : He has been strange of late and silent , laughs ,
Seeing the Cross , but softly and almost
As it were some sweet thing he loved .
ANTONIO
: As if
‘ Twere some sweet thing — he laughs — is strange — you say ?
Stranger than is Antonio his son ,
Who but for some expectancy is vacant .
: Stay , Fulvia , though I am not in poise .
Last night I dreamed of you : in vain you hovered
To reach me from the coil of swift Charybdis .
A woman 's voice !
And hasting here !

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: Go , then , Fulvia . ‘ Tis one would speak with me .

lg.l: : My Helena , what is it ? You are wan
And tremble as a blossom quick with fear
Of shattering . What is it ? Speak .

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: Not true ! O , ‘ tis not true !

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: Say no to me , say no , and no again !

lg.l: : Yes ; I am reeling , wrung ,
With one glance o'er the precipice of ill !
Say his incanted prophecies spring from
No power that 's more than frenzied fantasy !
: Who prophesies ? Who now upon this isle
More than visible and present day
Can gather to his eye ? Tell me .
: The monk —
Ah , chide me not !— mad Agabus , who can
Unsphere dark spirits from their evil airs
And show all things of love or death , seized me
As hither I stole to thee . With wild looks
And wilder lips he vented on my ear
Boding more wild than both . “ Sappho ! ” he cried ,
“ Sappho ! Sappho ! ” and probed my eyes as if
Destiny moved dark-visaged in their deeps .
Then tore his rags and moaned , “ So young , to cease ! ”
Gazed then out into awful vacancy ;
And whispered hotly , following his gaze ,
“ The Shadow ! Shadow ! ”
: This is but a whim ,
A sudden gloomy surge of superstition .
Put it from you , my Helena .
: But he
Has often cleft the future with his ken ,
Seen through it to some lurking misery
And mar of love : or the dim knell of death
Heard and revealed .
: A witless monk who thinks
God lives but to fulfil his prophecies !
: You know him not . ‘ Tis told in youth he loved
One treacherous , and in avenge made fierce
Treaty with Hell that lends him sight of all
Ills that arise from it to mated hearts !
Yet look not so , my lord ! I 'll trust thine eyes
That tell me love is master of all times ,
And thou of all love master !
: And of thee ?
Then will the winds return unto the night
And flute us lover songs of happiness !
: Nor dare upon a duller note while here
We tryst beneath the moon ?
: My perfect Greek !
Athene looks again out of thy lids ,
And Venus trembles in thy every limb !
: ‘ Twas on this temple 's ancient gate she found
Wounded Adonis dead , and to forget ,
Like Sappho leaped , ‘ tis said , from yonder cliff
Down to the waves ’ oblivion below .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: And will you read such terror in a tale ?

lg.l: Surely you are unstrung ,
And yet there is ——
: Nothing : I who must ebb with you and flow
A little was moved .
: Not you , not you ! I 'll change
My tears to laughter , if but fantasy
May so unmettle you ! Not moved , indeed !
Not moved , Antonio ?
: Well , let us off ,
My Helena , with these numb awes that wind
About our joy .
: Thy kiss then , for it can
Drive all gloom out of the world !
: And thine , my own ,
On Fate 's hard brow would shame it of all frown !
: Yet is thine mightier , for no frown can be
When no more gloom 's in the world !
: But ‘ tis thy lips
That lend it might . If I pressed other ——
Other !
You should not know that any other lips
Could e'er be pressed ; I 'll have no kiss but his
Who is all blind to every mouth but mine !

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: “ Oh — well ? ” — Then it is well I go !

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: There 's gloom in the world again . ANTONIOkissing her‘ Tis gone ?

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: Two for so small a gloom ?Kisses her again .

lg.l: The vainest glooms
To-night seem ominous — as cloud-flakes flung
Upward before the heaving of the west .
Oh !

sp.speaker: AGABUS
sp.p: O — lovers ! lovers ! Lord have none of them !

sp.speaker: AGABUS
sp.p: O — yes , yes , yes . You 'd give me gold To pray for your two souls .Crossing himself .Not I ! Not I ! Know you not love is brewed of lust and fire ? It gnaws and burns , until the Shadow — Sir ,Searching about the air .Have you not seen a Shadow pass ?

lg.l: : Silent and cold . A-times they call him Death :
I 'd have him for my brain — it shakes with fever .
( Goes searching anxiously .
: Yes , very calm —
Of impotence — as one who in a tomb
Awakes and waits ?
: Who is it ? soldiers come
From Arta ?
: And by this road !— They must
Not see us !

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: No . But quick , within this breach !

div.stage: They conceal themselves in the breach . The soldiers pass across the stage . The last , as all shout “ DI TOCCA ! ” strikes a column near him . It falls , and HELENA starts forward shuddering .

lg.l: : What now !
HELENA
: It is as if the earth were wind
Under my feet !
: Are all things thus become
Omen and dread to you ?
: O , but it is
The pillar grieving Venus leant upon
Ere to forget she leapt , and wrote ,
When falls this pillar tall and proud
Let surest lovers weave their shroud .

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: The shroud ! It coldly winds about us — coldly !

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: Should a vain hap so desperately move you ?

lg.l: : The breath and secret soul of all this night
Are burdened with foreboding ! And it seems —
My love , my lord —
Touch me lest I forget my natural flesh
In this unnatural awe !
Ah how thy arms
Warm the cold moan and misery of fear
Out of my veins !
: You rave , but in me stir
Again the attraction of these dim portents .
Nay , quiver not ! ‘ tis but a passing mist ,
And this that runs in us is worthless dread !

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: But ah , the shroud ! the shroud !

lg.l: : We 'll weave no shroud ,
But wedding robes and wreaths and pageantry !
And you shall be my Sappho — but through joys
Such as shall legend ecstasy about
Our knitted names when distant lovers dream .
: My lord , let us
Unloose this strangling secrecy and be
Open in love . My brother , Haemon , let
Our hearts betrothed exchange and hope be told
Him and thy father !
: It cannot be , and you a god ? I 'll bow
Before your eyes no more !— say that it can !
: Not yet — not now . Haemon 's suspicious , quick ,
And melancholy : must be won with service .
And you are Greek , a name till yesterday
I never knew pass in the portal to
My father 's ear , but it came out his mouth
Headlong and dark with curses .
: Yet of late
He oft has smiled upon me as he passed .
: On you — my father ? O , he only dreamt ,
And saw you not .
: Then have you also dreamt !
He looked as you , when , moonlight in my hair ,
You call me ——

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: Stay : I 'll call you so no more .

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: You 'll call me so no more ?

lg.l: : Why do
You say so — is it kind ?
: Why ?— why ? Because
Words were they miracles of beauty could
As little reveal you as a taper 's ray
The lone profundity and space of night !
: I 'll hold you not too false
If sometimes they trip out upon your lips .
: If he but look
Upon me for thy sake .

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: Gently , as one might in forgetting pain .

lg.l: : Perhaps : for some unwonted softness seems
Near him . But yesterday he called for song ,
Dancing and wine .
: Then tell him ! These are years
So dyed in crime that secrecy must seem
Yoke-mate of guilt .
: Antonio , love 's wave has cast us high
I would do all lest now it turn to fate
Under our feet and draw us out ——
: And is the world
Not space enough but he must needs come here !
If it were ——?
: I know not ! Broodings smoulder from his moods
Feverous bitter .
: Kindness then shall quench them .
But now , away . Forget this dread and be you
By day my lark , by night my nightingale ,
Not a sad bird of boding !
: With the day
All will be well .
: Remember then you are
Only a little slept from your life 's shore
Out on the infinite of love , whose air
Is awe and mystery .

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: I go , my lord . Think of me oft ! ANTONIOtaking her in his armsMy Helena !She goes with PAULA . He steps aside and watches the approaching forms .‘ Tis Haemon ! My father !

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: So , no farther ? you 'll stop here ?

lg.l: : Sir , if you grant it . I ——
CHARLES
: Some rendezvous ?
Who is she ? Ah , young blood and Spring and night !
: Some lay then you
Would muse on ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: And one of love ? The word , you see , founts easy to my lips .With confidential archness .‘ Tis recent in my thought — as you will learn .

lg.l: : O , when ? Be not surprised !—
Well , to the lay !
( He goes .
: Cruel ! His soldiers waste
The bread of honesty , the hope of age !
Are drunken , bloody , indolent , and lust
To tear all innocence away and robe
Our loveliest in shame !— Yet me , a Greek ,
He suddenly befriends !
ANTONIO
: Haemon ——

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: There 's room between your tone and courtesy .

lg.l: : And shall be while I 'm readier to bend
Over a beggar 's pain than prince 's fingers .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: And yet you know me better ——

lg.l: : Than to believe
You 're not Antonio , son of Charles di Tocca ?

sp.speaker: HAEMON
sp.p: So would he : and he smiles .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: There are deep reasons for it .

sp.speaker: HAEMON
sp.p: With him too ! Against a miracle , you are his heir !

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: I think it would be well for you to listen . My confidence once curbed ——

lg.l: : May bite and paw ?
Let it ! for fools are threats , and cowards . Were
You Tamerlane and mine the skull should cap
A bloody pyramid of enemies ,

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: Hear me . Will you be so blind ?

lg.l: : To your
Fair graces ? No , my lord — not so . Your sword
And doublet are sublimely worn ! sublimely !
Your curls would tempt an empress ’ fingers , and ——
: Let it speak
And not this subtle pride ! You would be friend ,
A friend to me — a friend !— Did not your father
Into a sick and sunless keep cast mine
Because he was a Greek and still a Greek ,
And would not be a slave ? His cunning has
Not whispered death about him as a pest ?
He — he , my friend ? and you ?— And I on him
Should lean , and flatter ——?
: Cease : though he has stains
The times are tyrannous and men like beasts
Find mercy preservation 's enemy .
You 're heated with suspicion and old wrong ,
But take my hand as pledge ——
HAEMON
: That you 'll be false ?
: I 've sought you , Haemon . Antonio ? We are
Well met then : to your doors my want was bent
With a request .
: Which gladly I shall hear
And if I can will grant .
: My haste is blunt —
As is my tongue .
: Then yield it us at once ,
Our mood is so .
: Haemon , I love your sister .
Not love : I am idolatrous before
Her foot 's least print , and cannot breathe or pray
But where she 's sometime been and left a heaven !

sp.speaker: HAEMON
sp.p: Therefore you 'll cry it maudlin at the streets ?

lg.l: : Necessity 's not over delicate .
Antonio , sue for me . You have been apt
In all love 's skill they say . My oath on it
Your words once sown upon her listening
Would not lie fruitless did they bid her yield
More than her most .
: Bardas ! Do you — Does such
Unseemliness run in your thought ?
: You 're strange in this request .
Helena , whom I 've seen , would little thank
The eyes that told her own where they should love .

sp.speaker: BARDAS
sp.p: I saved your life , my lord .

lg.l: : And I 've besought
Occasion oft for loaning of some chance
Worthily to repay you . If ‘ tis this ,
I am distrest . I cannot plead your suit .

sp.speaker: BARDAS
sp.p: You cannot or you will not ?

lg.l: : I have said .
Ask me for service on your foes , for gold ,
Faith or devotion , friendship you 're aloof to ,
For all that will and honor well may render
With nicety , and I 'll be wings and heart ,
More — drudge to your desire .

sp.speaker: HAEMON
sp.p: Nobly , my lord ! Bardas , you must atone ——

lg.l: : Peace
Is goad and gall ! Why do you burn my cheek
With this indignity ?
Do you ask why ?
A little since one of your father 's guard
Gave his command in seal to Helena
Upon the streets , to instantly repair
Unto his halls — which she must henceforth honor .
You knew it not ?
: O , well feigned .
Be sure none will suspect he is too old
For knightly feat like this — and that he has
A son !
: Bardas , you bring the truth ?— And so , my lord ,
You stab me through another — you , my friend ?
ANTONIO
: Do you mean that ——?
: Until this hour I held
The race of Charles di Tocca bold , or other
But empty of all lies in deed or speech ,
It grows — a little low ?
: Why you are mad !
Are mad ! I 'm naked of this thing , and hide
No guilt behind the wonder of my face .
For Paradises brimming with all Beauty
I would not lay one fancy 's weight of shame
On her you name !
: A pretty protest — but
A breath too heavenly .
: Leave sneering there !
You have repaid yourself — cast on me words
Intolerable more than loss of life .
You both shall learn this night 's entangling .
But know , between her , Helena , and shame
I burn with flaming heart and fearless hand !
( Goes angrily .

sp.speaker: HAEMON
sp.p: He can be false and wear this mien of truth ?

lg.l: : Ah , what !— “ He burns with flaming heart ! ” — have we
No flesh to understand this passion then ?
Bound to the wings of wide ambition he
Will choose undowered worth ?— To the ordeal
Of mere suspicion 's flaming I 'd not trust
The fairness of his name ; but doubts in me
Are sunk with proofs .

sp.speaker: HAEMON
sp.p: Proof ? He could not . No ! he dare not !

sp.speaker: BARDAS
sp.p: Yet the rogue Cecco , the duke 's half-seneschal , half-spy , I passed upon the streets o'ermuch in wine , Leaning upon a tipsier jade and spouting With drunken mockery , “ ‘ Sweet Helena ! Fair Helena ! ’ Pluck me , wench , but the lord Antonio knows sound nuts ! And sly ! Why hear you now ! he gets the duke to seize on the maid ! The fox ! The rat ! Have I not heard him in his chamber these thirty nights puff her name out his window with as many honeyed drawls of passion as — as — as — June has buds ? ‘ Sweet Helena ! ’ — la ! ‘ Fair Helena ! ’ — O ! ‘ Dear Helena ! my rose ! my queen ! my sun and moon and stars ! Thy kiss is still at my lips , thy breast beats still on mine ! my Helena ! ’ — Um ! Oh , ‘ tmust be a rare damsel . I 'll make a sluice between her purse and mine , wench ; do you hear ? ”

lg.l: : No more . When I had struck him down ,
He swore it was unswerving all and truth .
Hasting to warn I found Helena ta'en
And sought you here .
HAEMON
: Ah !
: Helena who is
All purity !
: Ah sister , child !— Have I
With strength been father and with tenderness
A mother been to her unfolding years
But to see now unchastest cruelty
Pluck her white bloom to ease his idle sense
One fragrant hour ?— If it be so , no flowers
Should blossom ; only weeds whose withering
Can hurt no heart !
: These tears should seal fierce oaths
Against him !
: And they shall ! until God wrecks
Him in the tempest raised of his outrage !

sp.speaker: BARDAS
sp.p: Then may I be the rock on which he breaks ! But hear ; who comes ?Revellers are heard approaching .We must aside until This mirth is past .They conceal themselves .Enter revellers dressed as bacchanals and bacchantes , dancing and singing . Bacchus , hey ! was a god , hei-yo ! The vine ! a fig for the rest ! With locks green-crowned and lips red-warm — The vine ! the vine 's the best ! He loved maids , O-o-ay ! hei-yo ! The vine ! a maiden 's breast ! He pressed the grape , and kissed the maid !— The cuckoo builds no nest !All go dancing , except LYDIA and PHAON , who clasps and kisses her passionatelyLYDIAbreaking from himDo you think kisses are so cheap ? You must know mine fill my purse ! A pretty gallant from Naples , with laces and silks and jewels gave me this ring last year for but one . And another lover from Venice gave me thisa bracelet— but he looked so sad when he gave it . Ah , his eyes ! I 'd not have cared if he had given me naught .

sp.speaker: PHAON
sp.p: Here , here , then !Offers jewel .LYDIAputting it asideThey say the ladies in Venice ride with their lovers through the streets all night in boats : and the very moon shines more passionately there . Is it true ?

sp.speaker: PHAON
sp.p: Yes , yes . But kiss me , Lydia ! Take this jewel — my last . Be mine to-night , no other 's ! We 'll prate of Venice another time .

sp.speaker: LYDIA
sp.p: Another time we 'll prate of kisses . I 'll not have the jewel .

sp.speaker: PHAON
sp.p: Not have it ! Now you 're turning nun ! a soft and virgin , silly nun ! With a gray gown to hide these shoulders that — shall I whisper it ?

sp.speaker: LYDIA
sp.p: Devil ! they 're not ! A nice lover called them round and fair last night . And I 've been sick ! And — I — cruel ! cruel ! cruel !Revellers are heard returning .There , they 're coming .

sp.speaker: PHAON
sp.p: Never mind , my girl . But you must n't scorn a man 's blood when it 's afire . Re-enter Revellers singing Bacchus , hey ! was a god , hei-yo ! etc . ( After which all go , except ZOE and BASIL .

sp.speaker: ZOE
sp.p: O ! O ! O ! but ‘ tis brave ! Wine , Basil ! Wine , my knight , my Bacchus ! Ho ! ho ! my god ! you wheeze like a cross-bow . Is it years , my wooer , years ?— Ah !She sighs .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Sighs — sighs ! Now look for showers .

sp.speaker: ZOE
sp.p: Basil — you were my first lover — except the duke Charles . Ah , did you see how that Helena looked when they gave her the duke 's command ? I was like that once .HAEMON starts forward .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Fiends , nymphs and saints ! it 's come ! tears in your eyes ! Zoe , stop it . Would you have mine leak and drive me to a monastery for shelter ! ZOEsings sadly and absentlyShe lay by the river , dead , A broken reed in her hand A nymph whom an idle god had wed And led from her maidenland .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: O , had I been born a heathen !

sp.speaker: ZOE
sp.p: He told me , Basil , I should live , a great lady , at his castle . And they should kiss my hand and courtesy to me . He meant but jest — I feared .— I feared ! But — I loved him !

lg.l: : Now , my damsel —!
ZOE
The god was the great god Jove ,
Two notes would the bent reed blow ,
The one was sorrow , the other love
Enwove with a woman 's woe .

sp.speaker: BASIL
sp.p: Songs and snakes ! Give me instead a Dominican 's funeral ! I 'd as lief crawl bare-kneed to Rome and mouth the Pope 's heel . O blessed Turks with their remorseless harems !— Zoe ! ZOEsingsShe lay by the river dead ; And he at feasting forgot . The gods , shall they be disquieted By dread of a mortal 's lot ?She wipes her eyes , trembles , looks at him and laughs hysterically .Bacchus ! my Bacchus ! with wet eyes ! Up , up , lad ! there 's many a cup for us yet ! ( They go , she leading and singing . He loved maids , O-o-ay ! hei-yo ! The vine ! a maiden 's breast ! etc .

div.stage: HAEMON and BARDAS look at each other , then start after them terribly moved .

div.head: ACT TWO

stage.stage: Scene .— An audience hall in the castle of CHARLES DI TOCCA ; the next afternoon . The dark stained walls have been festooned with vines and flowers . On the left is the ducal throne . On the right sunlight through high-set windows . In the rear heavily draped doors . Enter CHARLES , who looks around and smiles with subtle content , then summons a servant .

lg.l: : My lord , flowers and vines upon these walls
That seem always in dismal memory
And mist of grief ? What means it ?
: That sprung up ,
A greedy multitude upon the fields ,
Citron and olive were left hungry , so
I quelled them !
Magic ever dwells in flowers
To waft me back to childhood .
Poor pluckt buds
If they could speak like children torn from the breast .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: You 're full of sighs and pity then ?

lg.l: : Yes , and —
Of doubt .
: Helena —
This Greek — I do not understand .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Nor guess ? You have not seen nor spoken to her ?

lg.l: We 'll have her .
Go . Say that we wait her here ,
The lady Helena . ( Servant goes .
She 's frighted — thinks
‘ Tmay be her father found too deep a rest
Within our care : yet has a hope that holds
The tears still from her lids . I 've smiled on her ,
Smiled , Fulvia , and she — Why do you cloud ?
: Undone ? Undone ?
You would it were ——?
Enter HELENA .
Ah , Greek ! Our Fulvia ,
Who is as heart and health about our doors ,
Has speech for you . And polities
Untended groan for me . ( He goes .
FULVIA
: Girl — child —
: Why do
You call me so with struggle on your breast ?
: And was so free I thought
The world brimmed up with my full happiness .

sp.speaker: FULVIA
sp.p: But find it is a sieve to all but grief ?

lg.l: : Is it then grief ? I have not any tears ,
Yet seem girt by an emptiness that aches ,
Surrounds and whispers , what I dare not think
Or , shapened , see .
: It stains too as a shroud
The morrow 's face ?
: You look at me — I think
You look at me , as if ——?
: Why am
I in this place ? You fear for me ?

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: Yes ! A dumb dread trembles from you sufferingly .

lg.l: : It is not fear . Or — no !— has vanished quite ,
Ashamed of its too naked idleness .
HELENA
: He cannot , will not !— Yet you feared !
: Be calm :
Beauty is better so .
: Ah , you are cold !
See a great shadow reach and wrap at me ,
Yet lend no light ! By gentleness I pray you ,
What said he ?
: Child !— Ah , a moment 's dread
Brings age on us !— If not by gentleness ,
Then by that love that women bear to men ,
By happiness too fleeting to tread earth ,
I pray you tell the fear your heart so hides !

sp.speaker: FULVIA
sp.p: You are the guest of Charles di Tocca .

lg.l: : Guest ?
Ah , guests are bidden , not commanded .— Where ,
Where can Antonio be gone . All day
No token , quieting !

sp.speaker: FULVIA
sp.p: Antonio , girl ? Antonio ?— Is it true ? Re-enter CHARLES .

lg.l: : So eager ?— Truth
Has brewed more tears than lies . But , Fulvia ,
Why doth it mated with Antonio 's name
Wring thus your troubled hands ?
You falter ?
No matter — now .
But you , my fair one , put
More merriment upon your lips and lids ,
And this
upon the lustre of your throat .
Hither our guests come soon . Be with us then ,
And at your beauty 's best . Now ; trembling so ?—
Yet is the lily lovelier in the wind !
( He looks after , musingly , as she goes .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Twice — but I 'm not two lords .

lg.l: : To-night
I think you are . But quench your jests .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: In tears ? And groans ? Where borrow them ? FULVIAturning awaySo let it be .

lg.l: : Why do you say so be it and sigh as
Nought could again be well ?
FULVIA : O ——
: The hope you nurse , then , if it prove a pang
Of serpent bitterness ——
: Prove pang ? I then
But for an “ if ” must pluck it from me ?
: So
I must believe .
: Pluck it from me ! Will you —
Now will you have me mouth and foam and thresh
The quiet in me to a maelstrom ! This
Is mine , this joy ; and still is mine , though I
To keep it must bring on me bitterness
And bleeding and — I rage !
: Then shall I cease ,
And say no more ? No , you are on a flood
Whose sinking may be rapid down to horror .
And she — this girl ! It has been long since you
Gave license rein upon your will , and spur .
Do not so now .
: She is all morn
And dream and dew : make her not dark !

sp.speaker: FULVIA
sp.p: Wake her not , ah , not suddenly on terror !

lg.l: : Fulvia ,
Friend of my unrepaying years , dream you
I who in empire youth too soon forgot ,
Who on my brow surprise the wafted dew ,
The presages of age and death , shake not ?

sp.speaker: FULVIA
sp.p: I knew not , but have waited oft such words .

lg.l: : Ah what ! this hope , this leaping in me , this
White dawn across my turbulence and night ,
From license ?— Hear me . I have sudden found
A door to let in heaven on my heart .
Had I not laughed to see your dread upon it
Write “ license , ” perilous had been my frown .
: Yes — yes ! About her brow shall curl
The coronet ! Her wishes shall be sceptres
Waving a swift fulfilment to her feet !
Her pity shall leave ready graves unfilled ,
Her anger open earth for all who offend !
She shall ——
: Ah cease , infatuate man ! Will you
Build kingdoms on the wind , and empires on
A girl 's ungiven heart ?
CHARLES
: Unto such love
As mine all things are given .
: Stood she not as in pleading ? Yes — and to
Her cheeks came hurried roses from her heart .
And her large eyes , did they not drift to mine
Caressing ?— yet as if in them they found
The likeness of some visitant dear dream .
: Question no more .
She is set in the centre of my need
As youth and fiercest passion could not set her .
Supernally as May she has burst on
My barren age . Pain , envious decay ,
And doubt that mystery wounds us with , and wrong ,
Flee from the gleam and whisper of her name .
: And if your coronet and heat avail
Not with her as might charm of equal years
And beauty ?
: Then — why then — why there may slip
An avalanche of raging and despair
Out of me ! Hope of her once taken , all
The thwarted thunders of my want would rush
Into the void with lightnings for revenge !

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: With lightnings that shall —Sees him .You ? Antonio ? My eyes had other thought . Open your news — but mind ‘ tis not of failure .

lg.l: : We seized the murderous robbers in their cove
And o'er the cliff , as our just law commands ,
To death flung them .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: So with all traitors be it .

lg.l: : Well , ‘ twas swift . In you there is
More than your mother 's gentleness .
: Else were
My name di Tocca , sir , and not myself .
: You have my love .— But as you came met you
The cardinal ?
: So close he should by this
Be at our gates .
He 'll miss no welcome , and —
Perhaps — we shall —
Give me that cross you wear ,
My Fulvia . It may ——
: Sir , this is good !
We earnestly beseech of you to hear
The Pope 's embassador with yielding .
Ah ?—
But you , boy , draw out of this solitude
And musing moodiness . You should think but
On silly sighs and kisses , rhymes and trysts !
Must I yet teach your coldness youth ?
lg.stage: A trumpet , and sound of opening gates .
lg.l: Draw out !

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: I have to-day desired some words of this .

lg.l: : Then go ,
And bid our guests . Bring too Diogenes ,
Our most amusing raveller of all
Philosophies . Say that the duke , his brother ,
Humbly desires it ! ( CECCO goes .
: And Helena ?
CHARLES
Why do
You start , sir ?— Fulvia , we must look to
This callow god our son . Yet , had our court
Two eyes of loveliness to drown his heart ,
I 'd think on oath ‘ twere done .
FULVIA
: Listen . No word
Of Helena !
: Sir ,
He scorns to spill a drop of confidence
On my too thirsty questions .
: Does he so
Tightly seal up his spirits ?
: Put the rogue
To prison on stale bread , my lord : I half
Believe he 's full of treasons .
CHARLES
: Do you hear !
Because you are the son and scout our foes
Justice is not impossible upon you !
The guests enter , among them HAEMON and BARDAS , following the CARDINAL
JULIAN and his suite , and last HELENA , whom FULVIA leads aside .
: And more , lord Cardinal ,
We would to-day enlarge our worthiness
With you and with great Rome .
: Firmly I crave
It may be so .
: Here unto all our guests
We then do disavow our heresies ——
For faith 's as air , as ease to life — and seek
At your absolving lips release from our
Rough disobedience . Nor shall we shun
The lash and needed weight of penitence .
These words , great lord , fall wise and soothing well .
Who so confesses , plants beneath his foot
A step to scale all impotence and wrong .
Our royal Pope 's conditions shall be told ,
Pledge them consenting seal and you shall be
Briefly and fully free .
SECRETARY
: “ Whereas the duke
Di Tocca has offended —— ”

sp.speaker: CARDINAL
sp.p: Pass the offence . Be it oblivion 's . On , the penalty .

lg.l: : “ Therefore the duke di Tocca humbling himself
Must pay into our vaults two hundred ducats — ”
: “ And send a hundred men
Armed ‘ gainst the foes that threaten Italy . ”

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: See to it , yes , Antonio , ere a dawn .

lg.l: : “ He must also yield up the princess Fulvia
Who 's fled her father 's house and rightful marriage . ”
FULVIA
: You told me not of this — no word , my lord !

sp.speaker: CARDINAL
sp.p: My silence as my speech is not my own .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: We 'll more of it — a measure more . Read on .

lg.l: : “ And for the better amity and weal
Of Italy and Christ 's most Holy Church ,
He is enjoined to wed with Beatrice
Of Florence . If his wilful boldness grants
Obedience , his sins shall melt to rest
Under the calm of full forgiveness . He —— ”
: A mild , a courteous , O a modest Pope !
I must tear from my happiness a friend
Who fled a father 's searing cruelty ,
And cast her back in the flames ! And I must bind
My crippled years that fare toward the grave
In the cold clasp of an unloving hand !
No ! No !
Then , sir , and Cardinal , ‘ tis not enough !
I pray you swift again to Rome and plead
Most suppliantly that I for penance may
Swear my true son is shame-begot , or lend
My kin to drink clean of its fouling damp
Some pestilent prison ! And ‘ tis impious too
That any still should trust my love . Beseech
His Holiness ’ command for death upon them !

sp.speaker: CARDINAL
sp.p: This is your answer ? CHARLESrisesA mite ! a mite of it ! The rest is I will wed where I will wed Though every hill of earth raise up its pope To bellow at me thunderous damnation ! I will — I will —Falls back convulsed .FULVIAhastening to himCharles , ah ! Wine for him , wine !It is brought .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: Lord Cardinal , spare yourself more and go . You shall learn if a change may loose this strain .The CARDINAL goes with his suite amid timid reverence .CHARLESstrugglingI will — this frenzy — off my throat —! I —Recovering .Ah , Thou , Fulvia ? ‘ Twas as a fiend swung on me . And shame ! fear oozes out upon my brow , And I ——.Rises and calms himself .Forgive , friends , this so sudden wrench Upon your pleasure . One too quick made saint , Stands feebly : but at once wilt I atone . Where is Diogenes — where is he ? His Tangled fantastic wisdom shall divert us .DIOGENES , who has stood unconscious of all that has passed , is pushed forward .Ah , peer of Socrates and perfect Plato , Leave your unseeing silence now and tell us —— Enter AGABUS gazing anxiously and wildly before him . Who 's this ? AGABUShoarselyWhere went he — the Shadow ?— whither ?

lg.l: : Who 's this broke from his grave upon us ?
AGABUS
Where ?
I followed him — he sped and there was cold !
Behind him blows a horror !
lg.stage: Stops in fascinated awe before HELENA .
lg.l: Ah , on her head !
His touch ! his earthless finger !— and she rots
To dust ! to dust !
: Ill monk ! are there no men
That you must wring a woman so with fear ?

sp.speaker: AGABUS
sp.p: Ha , men ? Christ save all men but lovers ! all !Crosses himself .

lg.l: Sir , most mad
With the pestilence of evil prophecy .
Forth with him !

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: Let him not , for he will Beguile you to some ravening belief . AGABUSgoing up to CHARLES , staring at him in suppressed excitementA lover ! a lover ! and he loves in vain ! Wilt go ? There is a cave —taking his hand, we 'll curse her — come !

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Out ! out !Throws him from the dais .

lg.l: Christ save all men but —
Ah , the
Shadow !
Has no one seen him ? none ?— the Shadow ? none ?
( Goes dazed . Guests whisper , awed .
: O duke ,
I pray , good-night .
: Friends , you shall not — no . This pall will pass ,
My hospitality is up , you shall not !
: Though some grudging wind
Blows us away from mirth , ‘ tis still in view ,
We 've lute and dance that yet shall bring us in .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Cecco , our Circes from the Nile . ( CECCO goes .

lg.l: : Her own ;
And sinuous as Nile water is their grace .
Enter two Egyptian girls , who dance , then go .
GUESTS
: Bravely !— O , brave !

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Do they not whirl it lithe ? With limbs like swallow wings upon the blue ?

lg.l: : And thus ,
Did Cleopatra thus steal Antony ?
Wrap him about with motion that would seize
His senses to an ecstasy ? O , oh ,
To dance so !

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: And so steal an Antony ? We 'll frame a law on thieving of men 's heart 's !

sp.speaker: 2D LADY
sp.p: Then , vainly ! ‘ tis a theft men like the most .

lg.l: When in its stead the thief has left her own —
But shall we woo no boon of mirth save dance ?
A lute ! a lute !
Some new lay , Haemon , come !
And every word must dip its syllables
In Pindar 's spring to trip so lightly forth .
The lute !
Sing us of love
That builds a Paradise of kisses , thinks
The Infinite bound up in an embrace .
Whose sighs seem to it hurricanes of pain ,
Whose tears as seas of molten misery .
: Now will you fright off
Again our timid cheer ?
While she , my sister —!
I cannot , will not !
: Will not ? will not ? Look !
I had an honor pluckt to laurel it ,
A wreath of noble worth , a thing to tell ——
: Honor upon dishonor sits not well .
CHARLES
: Heat me not with denial . Is new bliss
Raised from the dead in me but to fall back
As stone ere it has breathed ? Have I so frequent
Drained you ? Be slow to tempt me — In me moves
Peril that has a passion to leap forth !
: Antonio , speak ! Where 's innocence and where
Begins deceit ?
FULVIA
: Ask it not , or you step
On waiting hazard and calamity .
: New fret ? and new confusion ? In the blind
Power and passing of this night is there
Conspiracy ?— plot of some here ? or of
That One whose necromancy wields the world ?
I care not !— I care not ! We must have mirth !
Have mirth ! though it be laughter at damned souls .
: And I must wake it ? I with laugh and lay ,
Doting upon dishonor ?

sp.speaker: HAEMON
sp.p: Give me again my sister from these walls , Since might is yours , strip from me wealth and life And more , and all — but let her not , no , no , Meet here the touch and leprosy of shame ! CHARLESlaughingSaid I not , said I , friends , we should have mirth ? You shall laugh with me laughter bright as wine .

lg.l: : But , sir , this is not good for laughter ! Sir !
HAEMON
: Ah , put the lamb on — bleat mock sympathy !
CHARLES
: Fulvia , O , he foots it in the tracks
Of your own fear ! and wanders to delusion !

sp.speaker: HAEMON
sp.p: Will you laugh at me , fiend !

lg.l: Had I but
Omnipotence a moment and could dash
Annihilation on you and your race !
lg.stage: Throws his glove in ANTONIO 'S face .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Omnipotence ? And could Omnipotence make such a fool ? There must be two Gods in the world to do it .

lg.l: She shall not ——!
ANTONIO
: Fury !— Ah ! what would you do ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Such things can be ? A sister , yet he strikes ?HAEMON is seized .

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: O let me speak with him , sir , let me speak !

lg.l: Not now , girl , no , not now — lest in his breath
Be venom for thee !
Shut him from our gates
Till he repent this fever .
lg.stage: To guests who are suspicious and undetermined .
lg.l: If you stare so
Will the skies stop ! Have I not arm in arm
Friended this youth and meant him honor still ?
Leave me . I had a thing to tell ; but it
Must wait more seasonable festivity .
See to thy mistress , child . Antonio , stay .

div.stage: All go but ANTONIO and CHARLES , who leaves his chair slowly and with dejection .

lg.l: : Father ——
CHARLES
: Did I not humble me ?
: Or ask more than a brevity of joy
To bud on my life 's withering close ?
: What thought impels and wrings
These angers from your eyes ?
CHARLES
: You 're like your mother .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: In trouble for your peace , more than in feature .

lg.l: : Peace — peace ? Antonio , a dream has come :
To stir — to wake — to learn it is a dream —
I must not , will not look on such abyss .
You love me , boy ?

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: Sir , well : you cannot doubt it .

lg.l: : There has been darkness in me — and it seems
Such night as would put out a heaven of hope ,
Quench an eternity of flaming joy !
I have sunk down under the world and hit
On nethermost despair : flown blind across
An infinite unrest !
: Had I drunk Lethe 's all ‘ twould not have stilled
The crying of my desolation 's want .
Within me tenderness to iron turned ,
Gladness to worm and gloom .— But ‘ tis o'erpast .
A rift , a smile , a breath has come — blown me
From torture to an ecstasy .
: Ecstasy !
Such as surrounds Hyperion on his sun ,
Or Pleiads sweeping seven-fold the night .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Is — you are pale ! And press your lips from trembling !

lg.l: : No — yes — well —
This ecstasy ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Is love ! is love that — How ? You feign ! distress and groaning tear in you !

lg.l: : O , Eve new-burst on Eden ,
All pure with the prime beauty of God 's breath ,
Was not so !
: She — Still you do not ail ?— Yes , Helena ,
Who — But you are not well and cannot share
This ravishment !— I will not ask it — now .
This ravishment !— Ah , she has stayed the tread
And stilled the whispering of death : has called
Echoes of youth from me ! and all I feared ....
I think — you are not well . Shall we go in ?

div.head: ACT THREE

stage.stage: Scene .— The gardens of the castle . Paths meet under a large lime in the centre , where seats are placed . The wall of the garden crosses the rear , and has a postern . It is night of the same day , and behind a convent on a near hill the moon is rising . A nightingale sings .

lg.l: : That bird ! Always so noisy , always vain
Of gushing . Sing , and sing , sing , sing , it must !
As if nobody else would speak or sleep .
: Let the bird be , my jaunty . ‘ Tis no lie
The shrew and nightingale were never friends .

sp.speaker: GIULIA
sp.p: No more were shrew and serpent .

lg.l: : Well what would
You scratch from me ?
: If there is anything
To be got from you , then it must be scratched .

sp.speaker: CECCO
sp.p: Yet shrews do not scratch serpents .

lg.l: : If they 're caught
Where they can neither coil nor strike ?
: Well , I
Begin to coil .
: And I 'll begin to scotch
You ere ‘ tis done .— Give me the postern key .

sp.speaker: CECCO
sp.p: Your lady 's voice — but you are not your lady .

sp.speaker: GIULIA
sp.p: And were I you not long would be your lord 's . Give me the key .

lg.l: : I coil — I coil ! will soon
Be ready for a strike , my tender shrew .
: Does the duke know you 've hidden from his ear
Antonio 's passion ? does he ?— ah ?— and shall
I tell him ? ah ?
: He likes well
What 's kept so thriftily .
CECCO
: You want the key
To let in Boro to chuck your baby face
And moon with you ! He 's been discharged — take care .
: The duke might learn , too , you 're not clear between
His ducats and your own .

sp.speaker: CECCO
sp.p: There thengives key, but —— GIULIAas he goesOh ? And shrews do not scratch serpents ? You may spy , But others are not witless , I can tell you !CECCO goes . Now , Naldo ( gives him key and writing, do not lose the writing . But Should you , he must not come till two . For ‘ tis At twelve the Greek will meet Antonio .

div.stage: NALDO goes , through the postern : GIULIA to the castle .
Enter HELENA and PAULA from another part of the gardens .

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: At twelve , said he , at twelve , beside the arbor ?

lg.l: : I were patient if the moon
Would slip less sadly up . She is so pale —
With longing for Endymion her lover .
: Has she a lover ? Oh , how strange . Is it
So sweet to love , my lady ? I have heard
Men die and women for it weep themselves
Into the grave — yet gladly .
: Sweet ? Ah , yes ,
To terror ! for the edge of fate cares not
How quick it severs .
: On my simple hills
They told of one who slew herself on her
Dead lover 's breast . Would you do so ?
Would you , my lady ?
: There 's no twain in love .
My heart is in my lord Antonio 's
To beat , Paula , or cease with it .
: But died
He far away ?
: Far sunders flesh not souls .
Across all lands the hush of death on him
Would sound to me ; and , did he live , denial ,
Though every voice and silence spoke it , could
Not reach my rest !— But he is near .
: O no ,
Not yet , my lady .
: Then some weariness
Has pluckt the minutes ’ wings and they have crept .
: But ‘ tis not twelve , else would we hear the band
Of holy Basil from their convent peace
Dreamily chant .
Nay , hearts may hear beyond
The hark of ears ! Listen ! to me his step
Thrills thro ’ the earth .
lg.stage: ANTONIO approaches and enters the postern .
lg.l: ‘ Tis he ! Go Paula , go :
But sleep not .
My Antonio , I breathe ,
Now no betiding fell athwart thy path
To stay thee from me !
Stronger than all betiding
This hour has reached and drawn me yearning to thee !
: All ! tho ’ we two will still
Be more than destiny — which cannot grasp
Beyond the grave .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: Ah , sadly , loathly ; but , my Helena —

lg.l: : I would not sink from it , the simple sun —
Fade to a tomb ! What dirging hast thou heard
To mind thee of it ?
: Love is a bliss too bright
To rest on earth . With it God should give us
Ever to soar above mortality .
But you must know ——!
Not yet , tell me not yet !
Dimly I see the burden in your eyes ,
But dare not take it yet into my own .
Let us a little look upon the moon ,
Forgetting .
ANTONIO
These hands — this hair —
: Like a farewell
Your touch falls on them .
ANTONIO
: To a father yield them ?

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: Antonio ? ANTONIOstill caressingNo , no ! It cannot be !

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: This dread — and shrinking — let me have it !— speak ! You mean — look on me !— mean , your father ?—

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: Ah ! It must not ! must not !

lg.l: : Do you mean — he — No !
Let him not touch me even in thy thought ,
To me come nearer than a father may !
: He 's swept by the sweet contagion of you , wrapt
In a fierce spell by your effulgent youth .
: Say , say it not ! To him I but smiled up —
But smiled !
: He knew not that such smiles could dawn
In a bare world . And now is flame ; would take
Your tenderness into his arms and hear
Seized to him the warm music of your heart .
O , I could be for him — he is my father —
Prometheus stormed and gnawed on Caucasus ,
Tantalus ever near the slipping wave ,
Or torn and tossed to burning martyrdom —
But not — not this !
: Then , flight ! In it we may
Find haven and new nurture for our bliss .
: Snap from his hunger this one hope , so he
Must starve ? Push him who has but learned there 's light
Back into yawning blindness ? Ah , not flight !
: I know he is your father , and my days
Have been all fatherless , tho ’ I have made
Me child to every wind that had caress
And to each lonely tree of the deep wood —
Oft envious of those who touch gray hairs ,
Or spend desire on filial grief and pang .
And most have you a softness in him kept ,
Been to him more than empire 's tyranny —
But baffled none can measure him nor trust !
: When waiting shall but goad
The speed of peril ?
: Still : and strain to win
Him from this brink .— If vainly , then birth , pity ,
And memory shall fall from me !— all , all ,
But fierceness for thy peace !
: I am thine ,
Thine more than immortality is God 's !
Hear , does the nightingale not tell it thee ?
The stars do they not tremble it , the moon
Murmur it argently into thine eyes ?
Ah , sorceress ! You need but breathe to put
Abysm from us ; but build words to float us
On infinite ecstasy .
: How , how thy kisses
Sing in me !
: From my heart they do but send
Echoes born of thy beauty mid its strings !
: Then would I lean forever at thy lips ,
Lose no reverberance , no ring , no waft ,
Hear nothing everlastingly but them !

div.stage: A mournful chant is borne from the Convent . They slowly unclasp , awed .

lg.l: : Weary with vigil does it swell and sink ,
Moaning the dead .
: Ah , no ! There are no dead
To-night in all the world . Could God see them
Lie cold and wondrous still , while we are rich
In warmth and throb !
: Yet , hear . The funeral tread
Of the old sea sighs in each strain , and breaks .
As I were drowned and heard it over me ,
It cometh — cometh !
lg.stage: Her head droops back on his arm . A pause .
lg.l: ANTONIO
: Cold ! cold !— your lips — your brow !
And you are pale as with a prophecy !
: Your spirit is not in you but
Afar and suffering !
: Awake from it !
HELENA
: A waste of waves that beat
Upon a cliff — and beat ! Yet thou and I
Had place in it .
: Come to yon arbour , come .
The moon has looked too long on the sad earth ,
And can reflect but sorrow .

sp.speaker: HELENA
sp.p: Ah , I fear ! ( They go clinging passionately together .

lg.l: : And yet it is a little thing to sleep —
Just to lie down and sleep . A child may do it .
: If my lord would , here 's sleep for him wrapped in
A quiet powder .
: Sleep is ever mate
Of peace and should go with it . I have slept
In the wild arms of battle when the winds
Of souls departing fearfully shook by ,
And on the breast of dizzy danger cradled
Softly been lulled . Potions should be for them
Who wrestle and are thrown by misery .

sp.speaker: CECCO
sp.p: And is my lord at peace ?

lg.l: : Strangely .— Yet seem
For sleep too coldly calm .
: So were you , sir —
I keep your words lest you may need of them —
On the same night young Haemon 's father went
The secret way to death .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Smirker !— Yet , was it so ? That night indeed ?

lg.l: : And the moon 's
‘ Scutcheon hung stainless up the purple east ?
: Half , sir ; even as now .
CHARLES
: Since that hour 's close
To this I have not stood in so much calm .
Still was he not in every vein of him ,
And breath , a traitor ? A Greek who — I 'll not say it ,
Since she is Greek I must forget the word
Sounds the diapason of perfidy .

sp.speaker: CECCO
sp.p: My lord thinks of the gentle Helena ?

lg.l: : Subtle ! your nothing harboreth some theft
Of spial .
That is
It does ! Must I — persuade it from your throat ?

sp.speaker: CECCO
sp.p: Have you not marked him sundry of his moods ?

lg.l: : On his back in the wood as if the leaves
Sung fairy balladry ; then riding wild
Nowhither and alone ; about the castle
Yearning , yet absent to soft speech and arms !
He 'll drink , sir , and not know if it be wine !
: So is he ! but to-day he bold unsheathed
His skill and bravery .
: And did not crave
A boon of you ?
: None . But you put not ill
My thought to it . His aspiration flags ——
: New wings it needs and buoyancy .
My trust in him is ripe : the fruit of it ,
He shall be lord of Arta — total lord .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Cunning ! again ? Sleek questions of a sleeker consequence ?

sp.speaker: CECCO
sp.p: It was , sir , only of Antonio .

lg.l: : Worm , you began so . Stretch now to the end ,
Or — will you ?
: I would say — would ask — and hope
There is no thorny hint in it to vex you ,
To prick your humor — may not he be sick ,
Amorous , mellow sick upon some maid ?
: Have you so labored to this atom 's birth ?
Is a boy 's passion so new under the moon
You gape at it ?
: I had thought
Would start up in your words some Titan woe ,
No human catapult could war upon !
Some dread colossal doom , frenzied to fall !
Were it he 's traitor gnawing at my throne ,
Or ready with some potent cruelty
To blight this tenderness new-sprung in me —
I would — even have listened !

div.stage: Noise is heard at the postern . It is unlocked . HAEMON enters , and stops in consternation .

lg.l: : Perchance also you have
Them to my gems and secrecies ? Shall I
Not show their hiding ?— rubies , and fair gold ?
: I could not : you
Have come at midnight — a most honest hour .
Enter this postern — a most honest way ,
And seem most honest — Why , I could not , sir !
: You wrong me , and have wronged me . I but come
To loose my sister .
: As to-day you would
Have loosed her with a piercing — into death ?
: Rather , could I ! Antonio — yet neither .
Since you , not he , are here , my passion melts
Into a plea . Humbly as manhood may —
: This fever ! Must I be
As ice while soiling flames leap out at her ?
And passionless — as one cold in a trance ?
Rigid while she in stealth is drugged to shame ?
Be voiceless and be vain , unstung , and still ?
I must wait softly while her innocence
Is drained as virgin freshness from the morn ?—
Though he were twice Antonio and your son ,
An emperor and a god , I would not !
: Ever ,
And ever bent upon Antonio ?
Be not a torrent , boy , of rush and foam .
Be not , of roar !— Yet — look : Antonio ?
You said Antonio ?
: Yes .
CHARLES
: You did ill
To say it ! He 's my son .
: Have
You cause — a ground — some reason ? Men should when
Suspicions curve their lips .
: No :
He is my son . His flesh has memories
That would cry out and curdle him to madness ,
Palsy and strangle every pregnant wish ,
Or bring in him compassion like a flood .
HAEMON

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Never !— Yet , a lurking at my brain !

sp.speaker: PAULA
sp.p: My lord Antonio ! my lady !Seeing CHARLES .O ! CHARLESstrangelyCome here .

sp.speaker: PAULA
sp.p: O , sir ! CHARLEStaking her wristWere you not in a haste ?

sp.speaker: PAULA
sp.p: I — I — I do not know .

lg.l: : Girl !— Why do you
Drop fearful to your knees ?
: ‘ Tis late , sir , late ,
Let me go in !
: You have a mistress who
Keeps quick temptation in her eyes and hair .
A shy mole too lies pillowed on her cheek —
Does she rest well ?
: Ah , you would say
She sometimes walks asleep : and you have come
To fetch her ?
: Or she has left
Her kerchief in some nook : you seek it ?
PAULA : O ,
Your eyes ! your eyes !
: I have a son : are his
Not like them ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: It was night , then — night ? You could not see him clearly ?

lg.l: : Mercy !
CHARLES
: Yet
Perchance he too walks in his sleep . Were it
Quite well if they have met — these two that walk ?
: My lady , my sweet lady !
CHARLES
Go , for she
Still wonderful may lie upon her couch ,
One arm dropt whitely . If you prayed for her —
If you should pray for her — Something may chance :
There is so much may chance — we cannot know !
This child who hath but dwelt about her , touched
And coiled the mystery of her hair , has might
Almost too much !

sp.speaker: HAEMON
sp.p: You cloud me with these words . Were they Antonio 's ——

lg.l: : If I but think
“ Helena ” must you link “ Antonio ” to it !
Can they not be , yet be apart ? Will winds
Not bear them , and not sound them separate !
If angels cry one at the stars will they
But echo back the other ?— This is froth —
The froth and fume of folly . You are thick
In falsity , and in disquietude .
Another rapture rules Antonio 's eye ,
Not Helena .
: You know it — yet have led
Her to his arms ?
His arms ! Ah , mole to burrow
Thus under blind and muddy misbelief !
To mine is she come here .
Were he a seraph ,
And did from Paradise desire to fold her —
No mercy !— But , I will speak as a child ,
As he who woke with Ruth fair at his feet ;
Long have I gleaned amid the years and lone .
She shall glean softly now beside me — softly ,
Till sunset fail in me and I am night .

sp.speaker: HAEMON
sp.p: This is a gin , a net , and I am fast !

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: A net to snare what never has been free ?

lg.l: : Still must it be this tenderness lives false
Upon your lips .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: “ Must , ” say you , “ must , ” yet stand ——

sp.speaker: HAEMON
sp.p: Then shall he rest — lie easy down and rest In treachery ?

lg.l: : Is it not open ?
CHARLES
: No :
Glooms start around me , glooms that seethe and cling .

sp.speaker: HAEMON
sp.p: This maid who called , did she come idly here ? You stir ? you rouse ?

sp.speaker: HAEMON
sp.p: And have not I come strangely on the hour !

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: You pause and ever pause upon my patience . ‘ Twill heave unbearably !

lg.l: : Then hear me , hear !—
Senseless against a bank I found a boy ,
Hurled by some ruthless hoof . Near him this key
And writing ——
: That avows , mid lines
Clandestine of purport , Antonio
And Helena , under these shades at twelve ——

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: You bring on me a furious desolation . But Fulvia , ah , she ——

sp.speaker: HAEMON
sp.p: Not there is trust ! She is aware and aids in his deceit . This writing says it of her .

lg.l: Fulvia ? No !
No , no !— Though she had sudden whispers for him !
A lie — Yet fast belief fixes its fangs
On me and will not loose me — for against
My hope she set a coldness and a doubt !
O woman woven through all fibres of me !
But he ——!
: Ah then , it runs in you , the rush
And pang that answer mine ?
CHARLES
: If they are still ——

sp.speaker: HAEMON
sp.p: Ah , God ! You will ?— you will ?

lg.l: : Hush ! something — No , it was
But fate cried out in me , not any voice .
: It cries again . I will
Not listen ! He 's not flesh of me — not flesh !
A traitor is no son , nor was nor shall be !
Though it shriek desolation utterly
I will not listen !
: And to-day
He shook , ashen and clenched , remembering
The guilty secret in him !
: My words fell warm as tears — “ A rift has come ,
A rift , a smile , a breath ” — men speak so when
They creep from madness up into some space
Whose element is love .
: And will you sink
To a weak palsy — who should o'erwhelm
With penalty !
CHARLES
: No ! all and ever false
Was he who 's so when most he should be true !
I will make treachery bitter to all time .
Bring dread on all to whom are given sons !
Down generations shall they peer and tremble ,
Look on me as on majesties accursed !—
Search every shade — search , search ! You stand as death .
I am in famine till he gives me groan !
( They go in opposite directions .
: Convulsed ,
Yet passionless ?
: Why were
You not asleep ?
GIULIA : I ——
: Did he beat his hands
Briefly — and then no more ?

sp.speaker: FULVIA
sp.p: And could not see ? But heard their names ? The Greek is still without ?

lg.l: : Your voice is guilty . How came Haemon in ?
Answer me , answer ! No , go quickly ! If
The duke has entered now and sleeps ! Or if ——!

div.stage: Words and swords are heard , then a shriek from HELENA . CHARLES rushes in furious and wounded in the arm , followed by HELENA , ANTONIO , who is dazed , and from Castle side by HAEMON , guards , etc .

lg.l: : You , you , sir ? father ? I knew it not , so swift
Your rage fell on me .
CHARLES
: Gaping , ghastly fool !
Do you behold him murderous and lay
No hand on him !
: Let him not fawn
About me ! Seize him ! God forgives not Hell .
Not this blood only but my soul 's be on him .
: Stand ! stand ! Touch me not with
Your voice or eyes or being ! They are soft
With perfidy , and stole me to believe
There 's sweetness in a flower , light in air ,
And beauty in the innocence of earth .
Bind him ! Leucadia 's just cliff awaits
All traitors — ‘ tis the law , they must be flung
Out on the dizzy and supportless wind .

sp.speaker: FULVIA
sp.p: But this shall never be ! No , though your looks Heave out with hate upon me . CHARLESconvulsed , then coldlyYou are dead , And speak to me . Once you were Fulvia — No more ! And once my friend , now but a ghost Whom I must gaze upon forgetlessly . Obey , at once ! and at to-morrow 's sunset !ANTONIO is taken and led out .HELENAfalling at CHARLES ’ feetYou cannot , will not — O , he is your son And loves you much !

lg.l: Touch me not ! touch me not !
Lead her away — and quickly , quickly , quickly !
lg.stage: HAEMON goes with HELENA through the postern . Friends — friends — ( unsteadily
lg.l: I am — quite — friendless now —?
Ah — quite !
: Charles ! Charles ! my lord ! return !— A numbness
Has barred the way of soothing to his breast !

div.head: ACT FOUR

stage.stage: Scene .— A chamber in the Castle , opening on the right to a hall , curtained on the left from another chamber . In the rear is a window through which may be seen silvery hills of olive resting under the late afternoon sun : by it a shrine . Enter the CAPTAIN of the Guard and a SOLDIER from the Hall .

lg.l: : That do I — every link of it ! I 've served
Under the bold de Montreal , and he
For stratagems — well , Italy knows him !

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN
sp.p: You must be quick and secret .

lg.l: : As the end
Of the world !
: Our duty 's with the duke . But then
Antonio has our love .
: That has he ! Ah ,
That has he !
: Well , be close . None must escape ,
Remember , none be hurt . As for the princess ,
We 'll hear the chink of ducats with her thanks .
: Madonna save her !— The Judas of a father
Who robs her rest !
CAPTAIN
: ‘ Tis she who comes this way .
So go , and haste . But fail not .
: If I do ,
Bury me with a pagan , next a Turk !
( Goes .
: Our plans grow to fulfilment — are
No way misplanted ?
: Lady , all seems now
Seasonable for their expected fruit .

sp.speaker: FULVIA
sp.p: No accident appears to threat and thwart them ?

lg.l: : Doubt not a fullest harvest of your hope .
The duke himself shall for this deed at last
Have benediction .
: May it be ! He 's quick ,
Though quicker in forgetting . I will move
Him as I may .
: The kind and wise assaults
Your words shall make must move him , gracious lady .
: I seek the duke .
FULVIA
You would seek penitence
Were you less far in folly .
HAEMON
: O — if he 's
Not here , then ——
: Sorrow too would strain your lips ,
Not cold defiance .
: Pardon : if you know ,
Where is he ?
: Was it easy to o'erwhelm
Under the ruin of her dreams a sister ?

sp.speaker: HAEMON
sp.p: Better beneath her dreams than under shame .

lg.l: : Your rashness cloaks itself in that excuse ,
Your ruth , and your suspicion that has doomed
One innocent .
: One innocent ! His thought
Had but betrayal for her !
: ‘ Tis the Greek
In you avows it , no true voice .
: Then ‘ tis
My father murdered whose last moan I hear
Driven about me in this castle 's gray
Cold spaces . And the dead speak not to lie .
: No , no . You cannot brave your action with
The spur of that belief .

sp.speaker: FULVIA
sp.p: This : ache and restlessness are on you . HAEMONimpatientlyNo .

lg.l: : And doubt begins in you that as a wolf
Will scent the wounded quarry of your conscience .
: After he lured and wooed her under night
And secrecy ?
: Not running there will you
Escape its dread pursuit .
: He frauded — duped
His father 's trust !
: Or there ! But one refuge
Have you against its bitter ceaseless tooth ,
And that above the wilds of self-deceit .
: Why do you wind so sinuously about me ?
No refuge can be from an hour that 's done .
Shall we invert the glass or tilt the dial
To bring it back ?
: Where is
The duke — I will not bauble .
: I will no longer listen to the worm ,
You set to feed upon me — torturing !
The sun melts to an end , and with the night
Antonio will not be .
: No matter : ‘ gainst the swell
And power of this peril you must lean .
HAEMON : I ——?
One that is sure .
But through those curtains , quick . For more seek out
The Captain of the guard . The duke comes hither .
( HAEMON goes through the curtains .
CHARLES enters , worn , dishevelled , and followed by CECCO . He sees
FULVIA and pauses .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: turning awayAh ! Nature should have pled With her your mother , ‘ gainst conception .

lg.l: : Your trust is causelessly withdrawn . Yet for
A breath again I beg it — for a moment !
: A moment were too much — or not enough .
Is trust a flower of sudden birth we may
Bid bloom with a command ?
: Ah , that it were ,
Or bloomed as amaranth in those we love ,
Beyond all drought and withering of ill !
But hear me ——!
: Will you not turn
Out of this rage ?
: Leave them , I say , and cease !
Still down the vortex of this destiny
I would not farther have you drawn .
: Then from
It draw yourself !
: Myself am but a hulk
Whose treasures have already been engulfed .
: A son , a friend , a — No ,
She was not mine !— I will not turn .
: It is
Your fury that distorts us into guilt .
Although he will not render up his heart ,
But flings you stony and unfilial speech ,
Fearing for her ——

sp.speaker: FULVIA
sp.p: Yet must I not until your will is wasted . CHARLESangrilyAh !

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: The hour ? CECCOgoing to windowIt leans to sunset .

sp.speaker: CECCO
sp.p: A murk moves slowly up . CHARLESwearilyThere should be storm — gloating of wind and grind Of hopeless thunders . Lightnings should laugh out As tongues of fiends . There should be storm .His head sinks on his breast .Suddenly .Yet !— yet !——

lg.l: : The glow and glory of her seem
Dead in me !
: And yearning has
Grown impotent — as ‘ twere a moment 's folly ,
A left and quickly quenched desire of youth
Kindled in me !— To youth alone love 's sudden .
: Cease : but a whisper of his name and I
Am frenzy — frenzy — though the stillness burns
And bursts with it !
: The sun , how hangs it now ?
CECCO
: Above the bloody waving of the sea ,
Eager to dip .
CHARLES
: Ah , I was in a foam ——
Bitten by hounds of fury and despair !
Did you not , Fulvia , pleading for them say
They quailed but would not flee and leave me waste ?

sp.speaker: CECCO
sp.p: She is not here , my liege .

lg.l: : Antonio !
Ah , boy ! thou ever wast to me as wafts
Of light , of song , of summer on the hills !
Soft now I feel thy baby arms about me ,
And all the burgeon of thy youth , ere proud
And cruel years grew in me , comes again
On wings and stealing winds of memory !
Yes . Fly , fly ! and stay the guard !
He must not — Ah !— down fearful fathoms , down
Into the roar !
Yet he has flung me from
Immeasurable peaks , and I have sunk
Forevermore beneath hope 's horizon .
Who falls so close the grave can rise no more .

sp.speaker: CECCO
sp.p: This your despair would wound him more than death . Forget the girl .

lg.l: : She ? Ah , my sullen , wild ,
And gloomy pulse beat with a rightful scorn
Against the hours that sieged it . Stony was
Its solitude and fierce , bastioned against
All danger of quick blisses — till , with fury
For that mute tenderness which women 's love
Lays on the desolation of the world ,
She ravished it !— Yet now ‘ tis still and cold .
: A woman 's smile
Never was luring , never , but she knew it ,
As hawk the cruel rapture of his wings .

sp.speaker: CECCO
sp.p: She though is young , and youth ——

lg.l: : Must pay with moan
The shriving !— Ah , the sun — the sun — where burns it ?

sp.speaker: CECCO
sp.p: Upon a cloud whence it must spring to night .

lg.l: : Red now
It rushes forth .
: A breathing of the world ,
And then !— Antonio !
: Again a cloud
Withholds .
: It dips , my lord .
CHARLES
: O , will great Christ upon it lay no fear !
Let it swoon down as if its sinking sent
No signal unto Death — and plunge , plunge thee ,
Antonio , forever from the day !
Has He no miracle will seize it yet !
Nor will lend now His thunder to cry hold ,
His lightning to flame off the hands that grasp ,
Bidden to hurl thee o'er !

sp.speaker: CECCO
sp.p: ‘ Tis sunk ! CHARLESrushing to windowYes !— Yes !Starting back horrified .The vision of it ! Ah ,— see you not , see ! They lift him , swing him — Now ! down , down , down , down ! The rocks ! the lash ! the foam !

div.stage: Sinks exhausted in his chair . CECCO pours out wine .

sp.speaker: SOLDIER
sp.p: Hear me , great sir , there 's mutiny !

lg.l: : And do the ranks
Of hell roar up at me ?— It is not strange .
SOLDIER
: The ranks of — pardon , lord .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Do the skies rage ——? They were else dead to madness .

lg.l: : Sir , it is
Your guard beyond the gates .
: ‘ Tis every throat
Of earth and realm unearthly has a cry
Against me and against !

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: You doubt it ?— Are my eyes not bloody ? Say !

lg.l: : My lips then are not pale with murder
Bitterly done ?
Yet have I killed ;
Spoke death with them — not reasonless — yet death .
And all the lost have echoes of it : hear
You not a spirit clamor on the air ?
Ploughing as storms of pain it passes through me .
Mutiny ? Go . I could call chaos fair ,
And fawn on infinite ruin — fawn and praise .
lg.stage: SOLDIER goes . Yet will not yield ! ( To CECCO .
lg.l: My robes and coronet !
( CECCO goes to obey .
I 'll sit in them and mock at greatness that
A passion may unthrone . If we weep not
Calamity will leave to torture us ,
And fate for want of tears will thirst to death !
Enter CARDINAL .
Ah , priestly sir .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Speak so . I lust for bitterness .

sp.speaker: CARDINAL
sp.p: What have you done ! CHARLESshuddering , then smilingWatched the sun set . Did it not , think you , bleed Unwontedly along the waves ?

sp.speaker: CARDINAL
sp.p: O horror ! Horrible when a father slays and smiles !

lg.l: : Not so , lord Cardinal , not so !— but when
He slays and smileth not .
: Therefore I smile . Men should not mid the trite
Enchanting and vain trickery of earth
Till they no longer hope of it , or want .
Smiles should be kept for life 's unbearable .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Well .Goes to shrine and casts it out the window .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: There are no wise men , O lord Cardinal .

lg.l: Heaven let Antonio 's death under the sea
Make every wave a tongue against your rest ,
And ‘ gainst the rock of this impenitence !
lg.stage: CHARLES listens as to something afar off .
lg.l: No wind should blow that has not sting of it ,
No light stream that it stains not !
CHARLES
: You have loosed
Your robe , lord prelate — see .
: Have peace . A keener cry comes up to me
Than frenzy can invoke : a vaster pain
Than justice from Omnipotence may call .
: “ Father ” moans it . “ Father ! ” ——
It is my ears ’ inheritance forever .
: Lord Cardinal , one of your servants has
In quarrel been struck , and mortally ‘ tis feared .
Quickly to him : then I may plead of you
Escort to Rome .
: Do not pause here to learn
With the dear minutes of a dying man .
( CARDINAL goes .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: You —?— Yes ! I am beat off by it .

lg.l: : Ten years of shelter
Have you held over me .
: Whose days ,
Whose every moment else had borne a torture .
: Must go ! Though in this castle 's aged calm
And melancholy dusk no shadow is
Or niche but may remember prayer for thee .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: To Rome ? You must ?— I am under a spell .

lg.l: : We , thou and I , after the battle 's foam
Or chase 's tired return , often have breathed
The passionate deep hours away in rest
And sympathy .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Say on . Your voice — I marvel ——

lg.l: : And at the dawn have looked and sighed , then slow
With quiet clasp of fingers turned apart .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: You go ?— But , on !— your tone — in it I feel ——

sp.speaker: FULVIA
sp.p: Have we not fast been friends ?

lg.l: : Such friends have we not been as grow up from
Eternity ?

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: You say it , and I wake .

sp.speaker: FULVIA
sp.p: Changed sudden as the sea when cometh storm .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: I had forgot — forgot !— the sun !— the sea ! The sea !— Antonio !— The cliff — the surf ! The shroud and funeral fury of the waves !

sp.speaker: FULVIA
sp.p: Be calm . CHARLESrising excitedlyI 'll stay it ! Cecco , our fleetest foot ! A rain of ducats if he shall outspeed This doom on us . More ! more ! a flood of them , If he —— FULVIAdrawing him to his chairBe patient — calm .

lg.l: : I — I — remember ,
‘ Tis night !
: The sun 's no more ! It hath
Gone down beyond all mercy and recall .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: You utter and he seemeth still of life .

lg.l: : He was a child in mimic mail clad out
When first this threshold poured its welcome to me .
: Softly you muse it , and call to your eyes
No quailing nor a flame of execration !
You do not burst out on me ? from me do
Not shrink as from an executioner ?
: I am a woman who in tears came to
Your strength , in tears depart .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: And will not judge ? But fear me — fear , and flee ?— You shall not go !

lg.l: : Again “ perhaps ” — this calm “ perhaps ! ” ——
To Rome ?— I say you shall not .
: Yet should he ,
Antonio , from those curtains come ——
: Should — should ?
You speak not reasonably . Why do you say
“ If he should come ? ”
: You 've touched
And led me trembling from reality !
Those curtains ?— those ?— just those ?— You shall not go .
: But something breaks from you ,
And as an air of resurrection stirs .
Speak ; on your words I wait unutterably .
: Did not a soldier lately come , my lord ,
Breathless with eager speech of mutiny ——?
: My guard ? No — yes ——
What do I see yet cannot in your words ?

sp.speaker: FULVIA
sp.p: The mutiny was roused at my command .

lg.l: : To save you the mad blot
Of a son 's blood .
: Low — low ——
Joy come too furious has piercing peril .
He lives ?— You have done this ? With these soft hands ,
These little hands , held off the shears of Fate ?
Have dared ? and have not feared ?
: Your danger was
My fear — that , and no more .
: He lives ?— I have
No worth , no gratitude , no gift that may
Answer this deed — no glow , no eloquence
But would ring poor in rarest words of earth .
He lives ?— Years yet are mine . Too brief they 'll be
To muse with love of this !
: But where is he ? Belief , tho ’ risen , strains
In me as if ‘ twere fast in cerements
That seeing must unbind .
My father !
Re-enter CARDINAL .
: Princess ,
If your decision and desire are still ——

sp.speaker: FULVIA
sp.p: Your eyes look upon flesh , lord Cardinal .A cry is heard , then weeping .ANTONIOstartledWhose pain is this ?— strangely it hurts me — strangely !

div.stage: Enter CECCO hastily , bearing robe and coronet .

sp.speaker: CECCO
sp.p: My lord , the lady Helen 's little maid ——

lg.l: : What of her ? Are you horrified to stone !
Her maid ?— There are than risen dead worse things
And worse to dread !— her maid ?
: Forth with it !
She direness of her mistress brings ? some tale
That earth elsewhere abyssless gaped her up ?
That butterfly or bud turn asp to bite her ?

sp.speaker: CECCO
sp.p: Sir — she — the maid craves audience with the duke .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: Fetch her , and quickly . ( CECCO goes .

lg.l: : Reason , Antonio .
She will but whimper , tell what overmuch
Of grief her mistress makes for you : of tears
Your sunny coming will dry in her .
ANTONIO
: These
Hours come not of any good , but are
Infected with resolved adversity .
This dread !——
: They ever dread who have but quit
The shadow of some doom and the dismay .
Re-enter CECCO , with PAULA weeping .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: I am no ghost . Thy mistress ?

lg.l: Mary , Mother !
ANTONIO
: Look on me . See !
I have not been down in the grave , nor ev'n
A moment beyond earth . Do you not hear !
PAULA
: Sir !
: Tell me .
PAULA
: Go to her ,
O , go to her .

sp.speaker: PAULA
sp.p: She , O !— go seek her , O , she is ——

sp.speaker: PAULA
sp.p: Blind all day she moaned and wept .

lg.l: : And when the sun was gone ,
Came quiet , kissed me — O , go seek her , sir !

sp.speaker: PAULA
sp.p: Then to me gave these jewels . O ! And darkly cloaked stole out into the night .

lg.l: : Ah , I do
Not know : but she ——

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: Pray , pray , tell out your dread .

lg.l: : Last night she said , “ My heart is in my lord
Antonio 's to beat or cease with it . ”
I learned her words — they seemed so pretty .
Charles
: Ah !

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: The cliff ! The —? ( Staggers dizzily , then rushes out .

lg.l: : Let one go with him — bring
Us what hath passed — hath passed .
( A SOLDIER goes .
PAULA
: My lady !
: Child ,
I cannot bear thy voice upon my heart !
It hath a tone — a clutch — no more , no more !
I cannot bear it ! We must wait . No hap
Has been — no hap , I think — surely no hap .

div.stage: Enter BARDAS deprecatingly , followed by ANTONIO .

sp.speaker: BARDAS
sp.p: Antonio ! not in the sea ? You live ?

lg.l: : You are mortal ?
ANTONIO
O
This utter superstition !
Is it not blood ?
: You live ! and live ? but let her think your death !
You let her ! still devising for yourself
Safety and preservation !

sp.speaker: BARDAS
sp.p: O , safe — if she had shrift ! CHARLEShoarselyThe dead are so !

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: And none above the grave ?— no answer ?

lg.l: : She came unto the cliff amid her tears —
Her being all into one want was fused ,
You down the wave to follow .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: But you grasped ——? You held her ?

lg.l: : Out of her breast she drew it swift ,
And instant of it drank .

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: Drank ? and she fell ? No ?— no ?— Ah but you dashed it from her lips ? She did but taste ?——

lg.l: : “ Is ‘ t not enough , ” she pled to me , “ Enough
That I must wander the cold way of death
Unto his arms ? Go hence ! There is no rest .
I will go down and clasp him , drift with him
To some unhabited gray ocean vale
God hath forgot . There will we dwell away
From destiny and weeping , from despair ! ”
: As I held her piteous hand
Came revellers who saw us — jested her
Of taking a new love . She broke my grasp ——

sp.speaker: ANTONIO
sp.p: And leapt ?— down the wide air ?

lg.l: : Swifter than all
Prevention .
: Helena ! O Helena !
That all thy loveliness should fare to this ,
Thy glory go in dark calamity !
: I saw her as she leapt and until death
Shall see no more .
ANTONIO
: Blot it from you ! Her face ,
Her sorrow and her fairness shall not stand
Imprisoned in your eye , tho ’ ‘ twere to cry
Relentlessly your crime .— But no — but no !

div.stage: Sheathing his sword , he pauses , then staggers suddenly out .

sp.speaker: PAULA
sp.p: Let me go to my lady !

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: Still her ! She Forever hath a fluttering , a cry , Undurably . It presses the lone air With sensitive and aching agony . PAULAwitlessly , in tearsI know thy song , my lady , I know , I know ! ‘ Twas pretty and ‘ twas strange , but now I know .Sings .Sappho ! Sappho ! In maiden woeLet alone love , it spurns and burns !Wept — wept , and leapt — O love is so !Let alone love , it burns !My lady ! O my lady ! my sweet lady !

sp.speaker: FULVIA
sp.p: This is most sad — most sad , and pitiful .

lg.l: : I cannot bear her voice upon my heart
Enter AGABUS gazing into the air .
Again this monk ? this dog of death ?— and now ?
My trusty Shadow
Ha , he has been here !
My king o ’ the worms and all corruption !—
Lovers , and lovers ! O she leapt as ‘ twere
To Christ and not sin 's Pit ! And he is gone
To follow her ! The devil 's nine wits are
Too many !
: My lord ! Your limbs are frozen ,
And bloodlessly you stand ! Move , rouse , O breathe !
It is not truth but madness that he speaks .

div.stage: A cry and clanking of armor are heard in the Hall . A SOLDIER bursts into the chamber .

sp.speaker: SOLDIER
sp.p: O duke ! O duke !Sinks to his knee .

sp.speaker: CHARLES
sp.p: gazes at him , struggling to speakRise — go — and , if thou canst — To pray .

sp.speaker: SOLDIER
sp.p: Sir —— CHARLESdesperatelyNone , fool ! but come to say what silence groans , What earth numb and in deadness raves to me . To tell Antonio hath gone out and o'er A precipice hath stepped for sake of love . This is not tidings — hath it not on me Been fixed forever ? It is older than Despair , as old as pain !To HAEMON , who has entered .Your sister ——

sp.speaker: CARDINAL
sp.p: Hold him not in this anguish .

lg.l: : She and our
Antonio have left us to our tears .
Let no one groan . I say let no one groan —
Fury on him that groans !
lg.stage: He blindly rocks to and fro .

lg.l: : My lord !
CHARLES
Well — come .
There 's much to do . We will think of the dead .
Perchance ‘ twill keep them near us : speak to them ,
And they may answer while we wait , may float
Dim words on moonbeams to us . O for one
That shall sound of forgiveness and of rest !
O I have started on the mountain 's brow
A tremor that has loosed the avalanche ;
And penitence too late — too late — too late —
Was powerless as flowers along its path !

div.stage: He sinks back into his chair and stares hopelessly before him .
